body: could you kindly paste some example code that is self-contained (e.g., on `sktime` data and including all the imports)

```python
from sktime.classification.interval_based import TimeSeriesForestClassifier
from sktime.datasets import load_arrow_head

classifier = TimeSeriesForestClassifier(n_estimators=100)
arrow_train_X_2d, arrow_train_y_2d = load_arrow_head(
    split="train", return_type="numpy2d"
)
arrow_test_X_2d, arrow_test_y_2d = load_arrow_head(split="test", return_type="numpy2d")
classifier.fit(arrow_train_X_2d, arrow_train_y_2d)

print(classifier.feature_importances_.shape, arrow_train_X_2d.shape)
```

Not sure I can do much this week to investigate this - can’t speak on behalf of other collaborators as well. 

Iirc we converted a lot of classifiers to match a specific, unified interface, so if this happens here it’ll be worthwhile to look at other classifiers touched to rule out any common coding error.
works fine with RandomForestClassifier but not with TimeSeriesForestClassifier.

can this be solved simply or should i look for another solution? 
thanks

@henrydeclety, I think the length is not a bug but expected behaviour.

If you read the docstring on how the algorithm works, this is the same as the pipeline
[random interval transformer] * [summary transformer] * [random forest],

with random interval transformer creating rounded sqrt(time series length) intervals, and [summary transformer] creating 3 features per interval (mean, std, slope).

For a series of length 251, as in the arrow head dataset, this is 15 intervals, times 3 is 45, which is what you get, it is the expected amount of features.

Unfortunately, it is not clear from the doc or the return object which entry corresponds to which feature, so that should be explained in the docstring (and possibly changed to a pandas series which has descriptive labels).

Changed the issue description to this effect.

rename.from: TimeSeriesForestClassifier feature_importances_ property returns less value than the amount of features in X
rename.to: [ENH] features in `TimeSeriesForestClassifier` `feature_importances_` property are not clearly documented or labelled

rename.from: [ENH] features in `TimeSeriesForestClassifier` `feature_importances_` property are not clearly documented or labelled
rename.to: [BUG] features in `TimeSeriesForestClassifier` `feature_importances_` property are not clearly documented or labelled

body: Okay i understand now, thanks. Then I just have a follow up question, is there a way to measure relative feature importance of different time series in a classification task? Like for example if ColumnEnsembleClassifier had an estimator_importance_ property or anything analog to that?
can you post a reference to what you mean with "relative featuare importane of different time series"? If it is a number per time series, it would be more of a leverage value than feature importance.

I mean the importance of each dimension if the time series input has multiple dimensions or the importance of each estimator if we fit a ColumnEnsembleClassifier. Is there anything in the sktime lib for that?

ah, I see - you get access to the individual estimators in a `ColumnEnsembleClassifier` via the `estimators_` attribute, or the `get_fitted_params` interface (the latter gives a dict like from `get_params`)

Is there an interval based estimator that can handle input series of different size without adding padding? 

What if I want to combine timeseries features with single value features? It seems like even the remainder columns in ColumnEnsembleClassifier need to be timeseries and can't be 1d values?
I always get `AttributeError: 'numpy.float64' object has no attribute 'iloc'` even when specifying the timeseries columns correctly in the estimators list. Thanks a lot for your quick answers.

> I always get `AttributeError: 'numpy.float64' object has no attribute 'iloc'` even when specifying the timeseries columns correctly in the estimators list. Thanks a lot for your quick answers.

Can you paste code for this bug?

> Is there an interval based estimator that can handle input series of different size without adding padding?

Maybe pipelines using the `RandomIntervalFeatureExtractor`, or `TSInterpolator`?
